docs.text: Qlang documentation Introduction Installation instructions can be found here . Qlang (Quick Language) is a programming language created in 2025 as a final project by a student. The language is not competitive with other languages and was created solely as an example. How does it work? Qlang works as a command translator to C#, i.e. the program first "translates" the code into C# and only then into a binary file. When compiling into .exe (or other executable files), the language simply compiles the C# program with your program class. What can I use it for? For anything, you can even write your own C# libraries for the language, which means you can use it in the same way as C#. The language also has a built-in library for working with Raylib (via Raylib_cs ). Instructions for use can be found here . Should I use it? If it's for serious use, then no. The language isn't that advanced, and it's easier to just use C#. My first program The creation of the first program is described here .
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Installation Instructions: Download the latest version of Qlang from the Github page (for your OS). Unzip the .zip archive. Move the folder with the compiler to a convenient location on your computer. (Optional, but recommended ) Add the following to the commands in your console: For Windows: add the values to PATH For MacOS: ... For Linux: ... Clap your hands and congratulate yourself on a job well done. A guide to creating your first program is described here .
docs.title: Installation

(Optional, but recommended ) Add the following to the commands in your console: For Windows: add the values to PATH For MacOS: ... For Linux: ... Clap your hands and congratulate yourself on a job well done. A guide to creating your first program is described here .
docs.title: Installation

docs.text: My first program MANDATORY: Before doing this, complete the section on installing the compiler! To create your first program, you should create a project . To create a project, use the new command: ql new [project_name] After that, a folder named [project_name] will be created with the program “Hello, World!” already written inside. To start the project (and compile it), use the command: ql run The compiler will automatically find the main.ql file, then create an executable file with the program and run it. The program usually runs in console mode.
docs.title: My first program

docs.text: MANDATORY: Before doing this, complete the section on installing the compiler! To create your first program, you should create a project . To create a project, use the new command: ql new [project_name] After that, a folder named [project_name] will be created with the program “Hello, World!” already written inside. To start the project (and compile it), use the command: ql run The compiler will automatically find the main.ql file, then create an executable file with the program and run it. The program usually runs in console mode.
docs.title: My first program

docs.text: Project The programming language uses a project structure for every program. This means that in order to create the final program, you need to create a project. Project creation To create a project, use the new command: ql new [project_name] A folder named [project_name] will be created. Each project contains the following files: project_name/ main.ql project.settings.json compile.settings.json main.ql - a file that will be processed by the compiler. project.settings.json - project parameters (name, as an example). compile.settings.json - compilation parameters (using debug mode as an example). These files are mandatory , and without them the project will be broken. Project configuration Project parameters can be configured using the set command: ql set [param] [value] [param] - the parameter that should be changed. [value] - the new value of the parameter. To obtain information about the current value of a parameter, use the get command: ql get [param] [param] - the parameter for which information should be obtained. Deleting a project Just delete the project folder.
docs.title: Project

docs.text: Just delete the project folder.
docs.title: Deleting a project

docs.text: Syntax The syntax of the language is similar to JavaScript, but also has elements from C++ and C#. An example of a program that will display Hello, World! in the console: // Adding a standard class package (in our case, the `Console` class) // This file must be added because it contains the core functionality of the language. include "$lib/base" // Creating the `main` function, which will be called when the program starts function main(): { // Call the `println` function from the `Console` class and pass the argument `“Hello, World!”` // To end the line, use `;` Console.println("Hello, World!"); } Class Creation To create a class, you need to write the keyword class and the class name: class MyClass : { // Function that will be called when creating a new copy of the class. // JavaScript equivalent: constructor function function new (): { } } Inheritance A class can also inherit other classes: class MyClass extends OtherClass : { // Class body. } Functions and variables from the OtherClass class will be added to MyClass . Creating a copy Creating a new copy: const myClassInstance = MyClass . new (); Functions Definition The definition can be made in class or in a file. When declared in a class, the private modifier is also available. When added, the function can be called only in the parent class. To declare a function, use the keyword function , the function name, and the parameters in parentheses (if any): function main (): { // Function body. } function functionExample ( const < String > var ): { // Body recived var (must be `String` type). } class MyClass : { // Acess only from `MyClass` (`MyClass.classFunction()`) or in `MyClass` (just: `classFunction()` or with keyword `this`) function classFunction (): { } // Access only in `MyClass` private function privateClassFunction (): { } } Function call To call a function, write its name and parameters in parentheses (if any): function main (): { // Call function. functionExample ( "Hello, World!" ); } function functionExample ( const < String > var ): { // Body recived var (must be `String` type). } Variables Definition Declarations occur in classes, functions, blocks, and simply in a file. When declaring, you should specify the mutability of the function ( const - immutable, let - mutable, as in JavaScript). When declared in a class, the private modifier is also available. When added, the variable can be called or changed only in the parent class. // Access available from anywhere // This method is not recommended because the variable can also be obtained in other files. const global_var = 1 ; class MyClass : { // Access only from or in `MyClass` const class_var = 1 ; // Access only in `MyClass` private const private_class_var = 1 ; } function main (): { // Access only in function `main` let name = "Volodymyr" ; } Get and change To obtain the value of a variable, simply write the path to it. To change the value, you need to write the path to it and then write equal and the value. class MyClass : { let var = 10 ; function myFunction () { // Change the value of `var` var = 20 ; } } function main () { // Now value of `var` is changed MyClass . var = 30 ; const myClassInstance = MyClass . new (); // Now value of `var` is changed in the instance `myClassInstance` myClassInstance . var = 40 ; }
docs.title: Syntax
